Raw milk also contains a variety of probiotics, similar to those found in fermented foods, which promote gut health and a strong microbiome. These natural components are largely destroyed during pasteurization, a process that heats milk to high temperatures to kill pathogens. In terms of safety, properly sourced raw milk—when obtained from clean, well-managed farms with healthy animals and hygienic milking practices—presents no greater risk than pasteurized milk and often less. The real risk comes from poor handling or unscrupulous production, not from raw milk itself.

Health benefits of raw milk include better tolerance among some individuals with mild dairy sensitivities, due to the presence of natural enzymes and beneficial bacteria that help break down lactose. Many people report improved digestion, fewer allergies, and even better respiratory health when consuming raw milk consistently. This is likely due to the immune-boosting properties and the diverse microbial content found in high-quality raw milk.

In summary, raw milk is not only safer when properly sourced but also more nutritious and health-promoting than its pasteurized counterpart. It supports a balanced gut, enhances digestion, and offers a more complete and natural form of nutrition.
